htmlEmbed:
Spillover of highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1 virus to dairy cattle - Nature2/3/2025

Spillover of the highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1 virus to dairy cattle and the findings of a clinical, pathological and epidemiological investigation in nine affected farms are reported.

Read

    <meta name="dc.description" content="The highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) H5N1 virus&nbsp;clade 2.3.4.4b has caused the death of millions of domestic birds and thousands of wild birds in the USA since January 2022 (refs. 1–4). Throughout this outbreak, spillovers to mammals have been frequently documented5–12. Here we report spillover of the HPAI H5N1 virus to dairy cattle across several states in the USA. The affected cows displayed clinical signs encompassing decreased feed intake, altered faecal consistency, respiratory distress and decreased milk production with abnormal milk. Infectious virus and viral RNA were consistently detected in milk from affected cows. Viral distribution in tissues via immunohistochemistry and in situ hybridization revealed a distinct tropism of the virus for the epithelial cells lining the alveoli of the mammary gland in cows. Whole viral genome sequences recovered from dairy cows, birds, domestic cats and a raccoon from affected farms indicated multidirectional interspecies transmissions. Epidemiological and genomic data revealed efficient cow-to-cow transmission after apparently healthy cows from an affected farm were transported to a premise in a different state. These results demonstrate the transmission of the HPAI H5N1 clade 2.3.4.4b virus at a non-traditional interface, underscoring the ability of the virus to cross species barriers. Spillover of the highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1 virus to dairy cattle and the findings of a clinical, pathological and epidemiological investigation in nine affected farms are reported."/>

    <meta name="description" content="The highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) H5N1 virus&nbsp;clade 2.3.4.4b has caused the death of millions of domestic birds and thousands of wild birds in the USA since January 2022 (refs. 1–4). Throughout this outbreak, spillovers to mammals have been frequently documented5–12. Here we report spillover of the HPAI H5N1 virus to dairy cattle across several states in the USA. The affected cows displayed clinical signs encompassing decreased feed intake, altered faecal consistency, respiratory distress and decreased milk production with abnormal milk. Infectious virus and viral RNA were consistently detected in milk from affected cows. Viral distribution in tissues via immunohistochemistry and in situ hybridization revealed a distinct tropism of the virus for the epithelial cells lining the alveoli of the mammary gland in cows.             <section aria-labelledby="Abs1" data-title="Abstract" lang="en"><div class="c-article-section" id="Abs1-section"><h2 class="c-article-section__title js-section-title js-c-reading-companion-sections-item" id="Abs1">Abstract</h2><div class="c-article-section__content" id="Abs1-content"><p>The highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) H5N1 virus clade 2.3.4.4b has caused the death of millions of domestic birds and thousands of wild birds in the USA since January 2022 (refs. <sup><a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Kandeil, A. et al. Rapid evolution of A(H5N1) influenza viruses after intercontinental spread to North America. Nat. Commun. 14, 3082 (2023)." href="#ref-CR1" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e684">1</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Youk, S. et al. H5N1 highly pathogenic avian influenza clade 2.3.4.4b in wild and domestic birds: introductions into the United States and reassortments, December 2021–April 2022. Virology 587, 109860 (2023)." href="#ref-CR2" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e684_1">2</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="USDA–APHIS. Detections of highly pathogenic avian influenza in wild birds. USDA–APHIS 
                  https://www.aphis.usda.gov/livestock-poultry-disease/avian/avian-influenza/hpai-detections/wild-birds
                  
                 (2024)." href="#ref-CR3" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e684_2">3</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 4" title="USDA–APHIS. Confirmations of highly pathogenic avian influenza in commercial and backyard flocks. USDA–APHIS 
                  https://www.aphis.usda.gov/livestock-poultry-disease/avian/avian-influenza/hpai-detections/commercial-backyard-flocks
                  
                 (2024)." href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#ref-CR4" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e687">4</a></sup>). Throughout this outbreak, spillovers to mammals have been frequently documented<sup><a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Puryear, W. et al. Highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) virus outbreak in New England seals, United States. Emerg. Infect. Dis. 29, 786–791 (2023)." href="#ref-CR5" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e691">5</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Cronk, B. D. et al. Infection and tissue distribution of highly pathogenic avian influenza A type H5N1 (clade 2.3.4.4b) in red fox kits (Vulpes vulpes). Emerg. Microbes Infect. 12, 2249554 (2023)." href="#ref-CR6" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e691_1">6</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Rijks, J. M. et al. Highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) virus in wild red foxes, the Netherlands, 2021. Emerg. Infect. Dis. 27, 2960–2962 (2021)." href="#ref-CR7" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e691_2">7</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Bordes, L. et al. Highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1 virus infections in wild red foxes (Vulpes vulpes) show neurotropism and adaptive virus mutations. Microbiol. Spectr. 11, e0286722 (2023)." href="#ref-CR8" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e691_3">8</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Plaza, P. I., Gamarra-Toledo, V., Rodríguez Euguí, J., Rosciano, N. & Lambertucci, S. A. Pacific and Atlantic sea lion mortality caused by highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) in South America. Travel Med. Infect. Dis. 59, 102712 (2024)." href="#ref-CR9" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e691_4">9</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Alkie, T. N. et al. Characterization of neurotropic HPAI H5N1 viruses with novel genome constellations and mammalian adaptive mutations in free-living mesocarnivores in Canada. Emerg. Microbes Infect. 12, 2186608 (2023)." href="#ref-CR10" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e691_5">10</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Jakobek, B. T. et al. Influenza A(H5N1) virus infections in 2 free-ranging black bears (Ursus americanus), Quebec, Canada. Emerg. Infect. Dis. 29, 2145–2149 (2023)." href="#ref-CR11" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e691_6">11</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 12" title="Sillman, S. J., Drozd, M., Loy, D. & Harris, S. P. Naturally occurring highly pathogenic avian influenza virus H5N1 clade 2.3.4.4b infection in three domestic cats in North America during 2023. J. Comp. Pathol. 205, 17–23 (2023)." href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#ref-CR12" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e694">12</a></sup>. Here we report spillover of the HPAI H5N1 virus to dairy cattle across several states in the USA. The affected cows displayed clinical signs encompassing decreased feed intake, altered faecal consistency, respiratory distress and decreased milk production with abnormal milk. Infectious virus and viral RNA were consistently detected in milk from affected cows. Viral distribution in tissues via immunohistochemistry and in situ hybridization revealed a distinct tropism of the virus for the epithelial cells lining the alveoli of the mammary gland in cows. Whole viral genome sequences recovered from dairy cows, birds, domestic cats and a raccoon from affected farms indicated multidirectional interspecies transmissions. Epidemiological and genomic data revealed efficient cow-to-cow transmission after apparently healthy cows from an affected farm were transported to a premise in a different state. These results demonstrate the transmission of the HPAI H5N1 clade 2.3.4.4b virus at a non-traditional interface, underscoring the ability of the virus to cross species barriers.</p></div></div></section>

                <div class="main-content">
                    
                        <section data-title="Main"><div class="c-article-section" id="Sec1-section"><h2 class="c-article-section__title js-section-title js-c-reading-companion-sections-item" id="Sec1">Main</h2><div class="c-article-section__content" id="Sec1-content"><p>The HPAI virus H5Nx goose/Guangdong lineage, an influenza A virus (IAV) from the family <i>Orthomyxoviridae</i>, emerged in China in 1996. This viral lineage was initially detected only in poultry, with detections in wild birds occurring in 2002 (ref. <sup><a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 13" title="Ellis, T. M. et al. Investigation of outbreaks of highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza in waterfowl and wild birds in Hong Kong in late 2002. Avian Pathol. 33, 492–505 (2004)." href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#ref-CR13" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e723">13</a></sup>). The virus has frequently reassorted with other influenza viruses, with the haemagglutinin gene remaining as the only gene that defines this genetic lineage of viruses. These frequent reassortments and ongoing antigenic changes led to complex classification of the viruses into multiple clades<sup><a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 14" title="Xu, X., Subbarao, K., Cox, N. J. & Guo, Y. Genetic characterization of the pathogenic influenza A/Goose/Guangdong/1/96 (H5N1) virus: similarity of its hemagglutinin gene to those of H5N1 viruses from the 1997 outbreaks in Hong Kong. Virology 261, 15–19 (1999)." href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#ref-CR14" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e727">14</a></sup>. Over the past decade, the H5Nx goose/Guangdong lineage evolved into eight clades (2.3.4.4a–2.3.4.4h) with three main neuraminidase subtypes: N1, N8 and N6. The H5N1 clade 2.3.4.4b has caused global outbreaks in recent years<sup><a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 15" title="Ali, M. et al. Genetic characterization of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N8) virus in Pakistani live bird markets reveals rapid diversification of clade 2.3.4.4b viruses. Viruses 13, 1633 (2021)." href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#ref-CR15" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e731">15</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 16" title="de Vries, E. et al. Rapid emergence of highly pathogenic avian influenza subtypes from a subtype H5N1 hemagglutinin variant. Emerg. Infect. Dis. 21, 842–846 (2015)." href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#ref-CR16" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e734">16</a></sup>, infecting various avian species and showing potential to infect humans and other mammals<sup><a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Puryear, W. et al. Highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) virus outbreak in New England seals, United States. Emerg. Infect. Dis. 29, 786–791 (2023)." href="#ref-CR5" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e738">5</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Cronk, B. D. et al. Infection and tissue distribution of highly pathogenic avian influenza A type H5N1 (clade 2.3.4.4b) in red fox kits (Vulpes vulpes). Emerg. Microbes Infect. 12, 2249554 (2023)." href="#ref-CR6" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e738_1">6</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 7" title="Rijks, J. M. et al. Highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) virus in wild red foxes, the Netherlands, 2021. Emerg. Infect. Dis. 27, 2960–2962 (2021)." href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#ref-CR7" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e741">7</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 11" title="Jakobek, B. T. et al. Influenza A(H5N1) virus infections in 2 free-ranging black bears (Ursus americanus), Quebec, Canada. Emerg. Infect. Dis. 29, 2145–2149 (2023)." href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#ref-CR11" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e744">11</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 12" title="Sillman, S. J., Drozd, M., Loy, D. & Harris, S. P. Naturally occurring highly pathogenic avian influenza virus H5N1 clade 2.3.4.4b infection in three domestic cats in North America during 2023. J. Comp. Pathol. 205, 17–23 (2023)." href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#ref-CR12" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e747">12</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Lee, K. et al. Characterization of highly pathogenic avian influenza A (H5N1) viruses isolated from cats in South Korea, 2023. Emerg. Microbes Infect. 13, 2290835 (2024)." href="#ref-CR17" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e750">17</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Adlhoch, C. et al. Avian influenza overview March–April 2023. EFSA J. 21, e08039 (2023)." href="#ref-CR18" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e750_1">18</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Harvey, J. A., Mullinax, J. M., Runge, M. C. & Prosser, D. J. The changing dynamics of highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1: next steps for management & science in North America. Biol. Conserv. 282, 110041 (2023)." href="#ref-CR19" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e750_2">19</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Elsmo, E. et al. Highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) virus clade 2.3.4.4b infections in wild terrestrial mammals, United States, 2022. Emerg. Infect. Dis. J. 29, 2451 (2023)." href="#ref-CR20" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e750_3">20</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Tammiranta, N. et al. Highly pathogenic avian influenza A (H5N1) virus infections in wild carnivores connected to mass mortalities of pheasants in Finland. Infect. Genet. Evol. J. Mol. Epidemiol. Evol. Genet. Infect. Dis. 111, 105423 (2023)." href="#ref-CR21" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e750_4">21</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Ulloa, M. et al. Mass mortality event in South American sea lions (Otaria flavescens) correlated to highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) H5N1 outbreak in Chile. Vet. Q. 43, 1–10 (2023)." href="#ref-CR22" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e750_5">22</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 23" title="Agüero, M. et al. Highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) virus infection in farmed minks, Spain, October 2022. Eurosurveillance 28, 2300001 (2023)." href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#ref-CR23" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e753">23</a></sup>. The World Health Organization (WHO) has reported 860 human infections since 2003, with a fatality rate of approximately 52.8%<sup><a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 24" title="WHO. Cumulative number of confirmed human cases for avian influenza A(H5N1) reported to WHO, 2003–2024, 28 March 2024. WHO 
                  https://www.who.int/publications/m/item/cumulative-number-of-confirmed-human-cases-for-avian-influenza-a(h5n1)-reported-to-who–2003-2024-28-march-2024
                  
                 (2024)." href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#ref-CR24" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e758">24</a></sup>, although serological evidence has suggested less severe more widespread infection<sup><a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 25" title="de Jong, M. D. & Hien, T. T. Avian influenza A (H5N1). J. Clin. Virol. 35, 2–13 (2006)." href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#ref-CR25" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e762">25</a></sup>. Risk of human-to-human transmission remains low<sup><a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 26" title="Sutton, T. C. The pandemic threat of emerging H5 and H7 avian influenza viruses. Viruses 10, 461 (2018)." href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#ref-CR26" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e766">26</a></sup>. Since 2016, the H5Nx clade 2.3.3.4b has circulated broadly in migratory wild bird populations across Europe, Africa and Asia, being first detected in North America (Canada) in December 2021 (ref. <sup><a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 27" title="Caliendo, V. et al. Transatlantic spread of highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1 by wild birds from Europe to North America in 2021. Sci. Rep. 12, 11729 (2022)." href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#ref-CR27" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e770">27</a></sup>). By January 2022, it was found in wild birds in North and South Carolina in the USA<sup><a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 1" title="Kandeil, A. et al. Rapid evolution of A(H5N1) influenza viruses after intercontinental spread to North America. Nat. Commun. 14, 3082 (2023)." href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#ref-CR1" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e774">1</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 28" title="Bevins, S. et al. Intercontinental movement of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) clade 2.3.4.4 virus to the United States, 2021. Emerg. Infect. Dis. J. 28, 1006–1011 (2022)." href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#ref-CR28" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e777">28</a></sup>, and soon after in commercial poultry<sup><a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 2" title="Youk, S. et al. H5N1 highly pathogenic avian influenza clade 2.3.4.4b in wild and domestic birds: introductions into the United States and reassortments, December 2021–April 2022. Virology 587, 109860 (2023)." href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#ref-CR2" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e781">2</a></sup>. Since then, H5N1 caused high morbidity and mortality in poultry leading to the loss of over 100 million birds (as of 13 August 2024) in the USA alone<sup><a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 29" title="USDA–APHIS. Detections of highly pathogenic avian influenza. USDA–APHIS 
                  https://www.aphis.usda.gov/livestock-poultry-disease/avian/avian-influenza/hpai-detections
                  
                 (2024)." href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#ref-CR29" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e786">29</a></sup>. The continuous and widespread circulation of this high-consequence panzootic pathogen is of major concern and poses a substantial threat to animal and public health.</p><p>In addition to devastating consequences to domestic and wild avian species, HPAI H5N1 virus clade 2.3.4.4b spillovers have been detected in several mammals<sup><a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 9" title="Plaza, P. I., Gamarra-Toledo, V., Rodríguez Euguí, J., Rosciano, N. & Lambertucci, S. A. Pacific and Atlantic sea lion mortality caused by highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) in South America. Travel Med. Infect. Dis. 59, 102712 (2024)." href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#ref-CR9" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e793">9</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 10" title="Alkie, T. N. et al. Characterization of neurotropic HPAI H5N1 viruses with novel genome constellations and mammalian adaptive mutations in free-living mesocarnivores in Canada. Emerg. Microbes Infect. 12, 2186608 (2023)." href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#ref-CR10" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e796">10</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 29" title="USDA–APHIS. Detections of highly pathogenic avian influenza. USDA–APHIS 
                  https://www.aphis.usda.gov/livestock-poultry-disease/avian/avian-influenza/hpai-detections
                  
                 (2024)." href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#ref-CR29" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e799">29</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 30" title="Plaza, P. I., Gamarra-Toledo, V., Euguí, J. R. & Lambertucci, S. A. Recent changes in patterns of mammal infection with highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) virus worldwide. Emerg. Infect. Dis. 30, 444–452 (2024)." href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#ref-CR30" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e802">30</a></sup>, including domestic and wild carnivorous species such as cats (<i>Felis catus</i>)<sup><a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 17" title="Lee, K. et al. Characterization of highly pathogenic avian influenza A (H5N1) viruses isolated from cats in South Korea, 2023. Emerg. Microbes Infect. 13, 2290835 (2024)." href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#ref-CR17" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e809">17</a></sup>, red foxes (<i>Vulpes vulpes</i>)<sup><a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 6" title="Cronk, B. D. et al. Infection and tissue distribution of highly pathogenic avian influenza A type H5N1 (clade 2.3.4.4b) in red fox kits (Vulpes vulpes). Emerg. Microbes Infect. 12, 2249554 (2023)." href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#ref-CR6" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e816">6</a></sup>, bears (<i>Ursus americanus</i>)<sup><a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 11" title="Jakobek, B. T. et al. Influenza A(H5N1) virus infections in 2 free-ranging black bears (Ursus americanus), Quebec, Canada. Emerg. Infect. Dis. 29, 2145–2149 (2023)." href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#ref-CR11" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e824">11</a></sup> and harbour seals (<i>Phoca vitulina</i>)<sup><a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 5" title="Puryear, W. et al. Highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) virus outbreak in New England seals, United States. Emerg. Infect. Dis. 29, 786–791 (2023)." href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#ref-CR5" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e831">5</a></sup>. The virus has even spread to polar regions, killing a polar bear (<i>Ursus maritimus</i>) in the Arctic, and elephant seals (<i>Mirounga leonina</i>), Antarctic fur seals (<i>Arctocephalus gazella</i>) and gentoo penguins (<i>Pygoscelis papua</i>) in Antarctica<sup><a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 31" title="Schnirring, L. Avian flu detected again in Antarctic penguins. CIDRAP 
                  https://www.cidrap.umn.edu/avian-influenza-bird-flu/avian-flu-detected-again-antarctic-penguins
                  
                 (2024)." href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#ref-CR31" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e848">31</a></sup>. In the USA, a human infection in a poultry worker that resulted in mild symptoms and full recovery was reported in April 2022 (ref. <sup><a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 32" title="U.S. case of human avian influenza A(H5) virus reported. CDC 
                  https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2022/s0428-avian-flu.html
                  
                 (2022)." href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#ref-CR32" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e852">32</a></sup>). During 2023, two major outbreaks of H5N1 in harbour seals resulted in high mortality in Maine and Washington. In January 2023, two indoor–outdoor cats died from HPAI-induced encephalitis<sup><a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 12" title="Sillman, S. J., Drozd, M., Loy, D. & Harris, S. P. Naturally occurring highly pathogenic avian influenza virus H5N1 clade 2.3.4.4b infection in three domestic cats in North America during 2023. J. Comp. Pathol. 205, 17–23 (2023)." href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#ref-CR12" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e856">12</a></sup>. Acute death of a striped skunk (<i>Mephitis mephitis</i>) in Washington has been reported<sup><a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 20" title="Elsmo, E. et al. Highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) virus clade 2.3.4.4b infections in wild terrestrial mammals, United States, 2022. Emerg. Infect. Dis. J. 29, 2451 (2023)." href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#ref-CR20" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e864">20</a></sup>, along with additional cases in this species in 2023 and 2024 (ref. <sup><a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 33" title="Shu, Y. & McCauley, J. GISAID: global initiative on sharing all influenza data — from vision to reality. Euro Surveill. 
                  https://doi.org/10.2807/1560-7917.ES.2017.22.13.30494
                  
                 (2017)." href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#ref-CR33" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e868">33</a></sup>). On 20 March 2024, the Minnesota board of animal health reported that a juvenile goat (<i>Capra hircus</i>) tested positive for HPAI, resulting in the first report of HPAI H5N1 infection in a ruminant species, following positive tests in backyard poultry on the same premises<sup><a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 34" title="Schnirring, L. Avian flu detected for first time in US livestock. CIDRAP 
                  https://www.cidrap.umn.edu/avian-influenza-bird-flu/avian-flu-detected-first-time-us-livestock
                  
                 (2024)." href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#ref-CR34" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e875">34</a></sup>.</p><p>Here we report the spillover of the HPAI H5N1 virus clade 2.3.4.4b into dairy cattle and describe the findings of a clinical, pathological and epidemiological investigation in nine affected farms (farms 1–9) across four states in the USA.</p></div></div></section><section data-title="Clinicoepidemiological investigation"><div class="c-article-section" id="Sec2-section"><h2 class="c-article-section__title js-section-title js-c-reading-companion-sections-item" id="Sec2">Clinicoepidemiological investigation</h2><div class="c-article-section__content" id="Sec2-content"><p>From late January to mid-March 2024, a morbidity event of unknown aetiology affecting dairy cattle was reported by field veterinarians in the Texas Panhandle and surrounding states (New Mexico and Kansas). The first farm known to be affected by the morbidity event (30 January 2024) was in Texas; however, no clinical samples were collected from affected animals in this farm. The disease was subsequently reported in additional farms in Texas and other states. We conducted a clinicoepidemiological investigation in nine farms located in Texas (farms 1, 2, 5, 6 and 7), New Mexico (farms 4 and 8), Kansas (farm 9) and Ohio (farm 3) that reported the morbidity event between 11 February and 19 March 2024. Farm 3 in Ohio was affected after apparently healthy lactating cattle were transported from farm 1 in Texas to this location (Extended Data Table <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="table anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Tab1">1</a>). Affected dairy cattle presented with decreased feed intake, decreased rumination time, mild respiratory signs (clear nasal discharge, increased respiratory rate and laboured breathing), lethargy, dehydration, dry/tacky faeces or diarrhoea, and milk with abnormal yellowish colostrum-like colour, thick and sometimes curdled consistency. In addition, an abrupt drop in milk production ranging from 20% to 100% in individual affected animals was noted. Upon clinical examination, mammary gland involution was observed in several of the affected cows (Extended Data Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Fig7">1</a>). The proportion of clinically affected animals ranged between 3% and 20%. Mortality above average (twofold higher) was noted in cows in farms 2 and 3 during the clinical event. Of note, several of the affected farms reported simultaneous mortality events in passerines (great-tailed grackles (<i>Quiscalus mexicanus</i>)), peridomestic birds (rock pigeons (<i>Columba livia</i>)), and in outdoor domestic (cats) and wild (raccoons (<i>Procyon lotor</i>) mammals; Extended Data Table <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="table anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Tab1">1</a>). The clinical disease in dairy cattle lasted 5–14 days, with animals returning to pre-outbreak health status, rumination times and feed intake, but maintaining decreased milk production for at least 4 weeks.</p></div></div></section><section data-title="Multispecies detection of the H5N1 virus"><div class="c-article-section" id="Sec3-section"><h2 class="c-article-section__title js-section-title js-c-reading-companion-sections-item" id="Sec3">Multispecies detection of the H5N1 virus</h2><div class="c-article-section__content" id="Sec3-content"><p>A diagnostic investigation was conducted in samples collected from farms 1 to 9. Initially, nasal swabs, serum and blood buffy coats from ten affected cows from farm 1 were subjected to viral metagenomic sequencing. IAV sequences were detected in one nasal swab and no other bovine respiratory viruses were detected. Real-time PCR with reverse transcription (rRT–PCR) targeting the IAV matrix and haemagglutinin 5 (H5) genes confirmed the presence of HPAI-H5 in nasal swabs of this cow. Of note, 8 of 10 milk samples collected from the same cows were positive for HPAI-H5 via rRT–PCR (Supplementary Table <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#MOESM3">1</a>). In addition, oropharyngeal swabs from great-tailed grackles and rock pigeons, and lung and brain tissues from a cat found dead on farm 1 tested positive for HPAI-H5 (Supplementary Table <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#MOESM3">1</a>). A similar epidemiological scenario involving mortality events in domestic and wild mammals was observed in farms 3–5 and 8. Six domestic cats died in farm 3 after the disease onset in dairy cows. Cats found dead on farms 4 and 5 and cats and a raccoon found dead on farm 8 tested positive for HPAI-H5.</p><p>Testing of multiple sample types (<i>n</i> = 331) collected from cows from farms 1 to 9 by rRT–PCR showed sporadic viral RNA detection in nasal swabs (10 of 47), whole blood (3 of 25) and serum (1 of 15), and most frequent detection in milk (129 of 192). The milk samples consistently had the highest viral RNA loads of the samples tested (Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Fig1">1a</a> and Supplementary Table <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#MOESM3">1</a>). Results from rRT–PCR on tissues collected from three affected cows revealed the presence of viral RNA in the lungs, small intestines, supramammary lymph nodes and mammary glands. The highest viral RNA loads were detected in the mammary glands (Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Fig1">1b</a> and Supplementary Table <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#MOESM3">1</a>), corroborating high viral loads detected in milk. In addition, haemagglutination inhibition antibody testing in paired serum samples collected from animals in farm 2 (<i>n</i> = 19) confirmed H5N1 infection in affected dairy cows (Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Fig1">1c</a>).</p><div class="c-article-section__figure js-c-reading-companion-figures-item" data-test="figure" data-container-section="figure" id="figure-1" data-title="Detection and isolation of HPAI H5N1 from dairy cattle."><figure><figcaption><b id="Fig1" class="c-article-section__figure-caption" data-test="figure-caption-text">Fig. 1: Detection and isolation of HPAI H5N1 from dairy cattle.</b></figcaption><div class="c-article-section__figure-content"><div class="c-article-section__figure-item"><a class="c-article-section__figure-link" data-test="img-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="image" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4/figures/1" rel="nofollow"><picture><source type="image/webp" srcset="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41586-024-07849-4/MediaObjects/41586_2024_7849_Fig1_HTML.png?as=webp"><img aria-describedby="Fig1" src="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41586-024-07849-4/MediaObjects/41586_2024_7849_Fig1_HTML.png" alt="figure 1" loading="lazy" width="685" height="909"></picture></a></div><div class="c-article-section__figure-description" data-test="bottom-caption" id="figure-1-desc"><p><b>a</b>, Viral RNA loads in nasal swab (<i>n</i> = 27), whole-blood (<i>n</i> = 25), serum (<i>n</i> = 15), urine (<i>n</i> = 4), faecal (<i>n</i> = 10) and milk (<i>n</i> = 167) samples collected from cattle from farms 1 to 9 quantified by rRT–PCR targeting the IAV matrix gene. <b>b</b>, Viral RNA loads in tissues of dairy cattle quantified by rRT–PCR targeting the IAV matrix gene. <b>c</b>, Serum antibody responses in affected cattle (<i>n</i> = 19) quantified by a haemagglutination inhibition (HI) assay. <b>d</b>, Cytopathic effect of the HPAI H5N1 virus isolated from milk in bovine uterine epithelial cells Cal-1. The photomicrographs shown are representative of two independent clinical samples. Scale bar, 50 µm. <b>e</b>, Detection of the infectious HPAI virus in Cal-1 cells by an immunofluorescence assay using a nucleoprotein-specific monoclonal antibody (red) counterstained with 4′,6-diamidino-2-phenylindole (DAPI, blue). The photomicrographs shown are representative of two independent clinical samples. Scale bar, 50 µm. <b>f</b>,<b>g</b>, Infectious HPAI H5N1 virus in milk (<i>n</i> = 69; <b>f</b>) and tissues (<b>g</b>) detected by virus titration. Virus titres were determined using end point dilutions and expressed as 50% tissue culture infectious dose (TCID<sub>50</sub>) per millilitre (TCID<sub>50</sub> ml<sup>−1</sup>). The limit of detection for infectious virus titration was 10<sup>1.05</sup> TCID<sub>50</sub> ml<sup>−1</sup>. Data are presented as mean ± s.e.m (<b>a</b>–<b>c</b>,<b>f</b>,<b>g</b>). All graphs and statistical analysis were generated using GraphPad Prism (v10).</p><p><a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#MOESM10">Source Data</a></p></div></div><div class="u-text-right u-hide-print"><a class="c-article__pill-button" data-test="article-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="button" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4/figures/1" data-track-dest="link:Figure1 Full size image" aria-label="Full size image figure 1" rel="nofollow"><span>Full size image</span><svg width="16" height="16" focusable="false" role="img" aria-hidden="true" class="u-icon"><use xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="#icon-eds-i-chevron-right-small"></use></svg></a></div></figure></div></div></div></section><section data-title="Infectious virus shedding in dairy cows"><div class="c-article-section" id="Sec4-section"><h2 class="c-article-section__title js-section-title js-c-reading-companion-sections-item" id="Sec4">Infectious virus shedding in dairy cows</h2><div class="c-article-section__content" id="Sec4-content"><p>Virus isolation and quantification were performed on milk samples from farms 1, 2 and 3. Infectious HPAI H5N1 virus was isolated from the pellet of pooled milk samples from 10 cows from farms 1 and 2 (Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Fig1">1d,e</a>). Of note, virus titres in milk from affected animals ranged from 10<sup>4.0</sup> to 10<sup>8.8</sup> 50% tissue culture infectious dose (TCID<sub>50</sub>) per millilitre (Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Fig1">1f</a>), demonstrating high infectious viral loads in milk from infected animals. Consistent with this, high viral loads (10<sup>7.3</sup>–10<sup>7.8</sup> TCID<sub>50</sub> ml<sup>−1</sup>) were detected in mammary gland tissues (Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Fig1">1g</a>).</p><p>Virus shedding was also investigated in samples (milk, nasal swabs, urine and faeces) collected from clinical and non-clinical animals from farm 3. Overall, virus shedding was detected more frequently in milk samples from clinical animals (24 of 25) with higher RNA viral loads than from non-clinical animals (1 of 15; Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Fig2">2a</a> and Extended Data Table <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="table anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Tab2">2</a>). Clinical animals shed virus at a low frequency in nasal swabs (6 of 25) and urine (2 of 15), and no viral RNA was detected in faeces (Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Fig2">2a</a> and Extended Data Table <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="table anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Tab2">2</a>). In non-clinical animals, viral RNA was detected in 6 of 19 nasal swabs and 4 of 8 urine samples (Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Fig2">2a</a> and Extended Data Table <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="table anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Tab2">2</a>), indicating subclinical infection.</p><div class="c-article-section__figure js-c-reading-companion-figures-item" data-test="figure" data-container-section="figure" id="figure-2" data-title="Virus shedding patterns."><figure><figcaption><b id="Fig2" class="c-article-section__figure-caption" data-test="figure-caption-text">Fig. 2: Virus shedding patterns.</b></figcaption><div class="c-article-section__figure-content"><div class="c-article-section__figure-item"><a class="c-article-section__figure-link" data-test="img-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="image" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4/figures/2" rel="nofollow"><picture><source type="image/webp" srcset="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41586-024-07849-4/MediaObjects/41586_2024_7849_Fig2_HTML.png?as=webp"><img aria-describedby="Fig2" src="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41586-024-07849-4/MediaObjects/41586_2024_7849_Fig2_HTML.png" alt="figure 2" loading="lazy" width="685" height="250"></picture></a></div><div class="c-article-section__figure-description" data-test="bottom-caption" id="figure-2-desc"><p><b>a</b>, Viral shedding and RNA load in milk (<i>n</i> = 41), nasal secretions (nasal swabs, <i>n</i> = 45), urine (<i>n</i> = 23) and faeces (<i>n</i> = 25) collected from clinical and non-clinical animals from farm 3. <b>b</b>, Viral RNA loads in milk samples collected from cattle from farm 3 on day 3 (<i>n</i> = 15), day 16 (<i>n</i> = 12) and day 31 (<i>n</i> = 9) post-clinical diagnosis quantified by rRT–PCR targeting the IAV matrix gene. <b>c</b>, Infectious HPAI virus in milk (<i>n</i> = 13 on day 3, <i>n</i> = 12 on day 16 and <i>n</i> = 9 on day 31) detected by virus titration. Virus titres were determined using end point dilutions and expressed as TCID<sub>50</sub> ml<sup>−1</sup>. The limit of detection for infectious virus titration was 10<sup>1.05</sup> TCID<sub>50</sub> ml<sup>−1</sup>. Data are presented as mean ± s.e.m. All graphs and statistical analysis were generated using GraphPad Prism (v10).</p><p><a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#MOESM11">Source Data</a></p></div></div><div class="u-text-right u-hide-print"><a class="c-article__pill-button" data-test="article-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="button" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4/figures/2" data-track-dest="link:Figure2 Full size image" aria-label="Full size image figure 2" rel="nofollow"><span>Full size image</span><svg width="16" height="16" focusable="false" role="img" aria-hidden="true" class="u-icon"><use xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="#icon-eds-i-chevron-right-small"></use></svg></a></div></figure></div></div></div></section><section data-title="Duration of H5N1 virus shedding"><div class="c-article-section" id="Sec5-section"><h2 class="c-article-section__title js-section-title js-c-reading-companion-sections-item" id="Sec5">Duration of H5N1 virus shedding</h2><div class="c-article-section__content" id="Sec5-content"><p>Nasal swabs, whole blood, serum and milk samples were collected at approximately 3 (<i>n</i> = 15), 16 (<i>n</i> = 12) and 31 (<i>n</i> = 9) days post-clinical diagnosis of HPAI to assess the duration of virus shedding. On day 3, viral RNA was detected in nasal swabs from 2 of 15 animals, in whole blood of 1 of 15 animals, in serum of 1 of 15 animals, and in milk of 14 of 15 animals (Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Fig2">2b</a> and Supplementary Table <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#MOESM4">2</a>). Although no virus RNA was detected in nasal swabs, whole-blood or serum samples collected on days 16 and 31 post-clinical diagnosis, milk from 10 of 12 and 4 of 9 animals tested on days 16 and 31 post-clinical diagnosis, respectively, remained positive (Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Fig2">2b</a> and Supplementary Table <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#MOESM4">2</a>). Although high infectious viral loads were detected in milk on day 3 post-clinical diagnosis (10<sup>4.05</sup>–10<sup>8.80</sup> TCID<sub>50</sub> ml<sup>−1</sup>), no infectious virus was recovered from milk from days 16 and 31 post-clinical diagnosis (Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Fig2">2c</a>).</p></div></div></section><section data-title="Mammary gland tropism of the H5N1 virus"><div class="c-article-section" id="Sec6-section"><h2 class="c-article-section__title js-section-title js-c-reading-companion-sections-item" id="Sec6">Mammary gland tropism of the H5N1 virus</h2><div class="c-article-section__content" id="Sec6-content"><p>Histological examination of tissues from affected dairy cows revealed marked changes consisting of neutrophilic and lymphoplasmacytic mastitis with prominent effacement of tubuloacinar gland architecture, which were filled with neutrophils admixed with cellular debris in multiple lobules in the mammary gland (Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Fig3">3</a>). The most pronounced histological changes in the cat tissues consisted of mild-to-moderate multifocal lymphohistiocytic meningoencephalitis with multifocal areas of parenchymal and neuronal necrosis (Extended Data Table <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="table anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Tab6">6</a> and Extended Data Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Fig8">2</a>).</p><div class="c-article-section__figure js-c-reading-companion-figures-item" data-test="figure" data-container-section="figure" id="figure-3" data-title="Detection of HPAI H5N1 in dairy cattle mammary gland tissue."><figure><figcaption><b id="Fig3" class="c-article-section__figure-caption" data-test="figure-caption-text">Fig. 3: Detection of HPAI H5N1 in dairy cattle mammary gland tissue.</b></figcaption><div class="c-article-section__figure-content"><div class="c-article-section__figure-item"><a class="c-article-section__figure-link" data-test="img-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="image" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4/figures/3" rel="nofollow"><picture><source type="image/webp" srcset="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41586-024-07849-4/MediaObjects/41586_2024_7849_Fig3_HTML.png?as=webp"><img aria-describedby="Fig3" src="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41586-024-07849-4/MediaObjects/41586_2024_7849_Fig3_HTML.png" alt="figure 3" loading="lazy" width="685" height="517"></picture></a></div><div class="c-article-section__figure-description" data-test="bottom-caption" id="figure-3-desc"><p>Haematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining (left panels) showing intraluminal epithelial sloughing and cellular debris in mammary alveoli (Z1 and Z2), and normal mammary alveoli filled with milk and fat globules (Z3). In situ hybridization (ISH; middle panels) targeting the IAV (matrix gene) showing extensive viral RNA in milk-secreting epithelial cells in the alveoli and in intraluminal cellular debris (Z1 and Z2), and normal mammary alveoli showing no viral staining (Z3). Immunohistochemistry (IHC; right panels) targeting the IAV matrix gene showing intracytoplasmic immunolabelling of viral antigen in milk-secreting alveolar epithelial cells (Z1 and Z2), and normal mammary alveoli showing no viral staining (Z3). Scale bars, 500 µm (Z0) and 50 µm (Z1–Z3).</p></div></div><div class="u-text-right u-hide-print"><a class="c-article__pill-button" data-test="article-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="button" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4/figures/3" data-track-dest="link:Figure3 Full size image" aria-label="Full size image figure 3" rel="nofollow"><span>Full size image</span><svg width="16" height="16" focusable="false" role="img" aria-hidden="true" class="u-icon"><use xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="#icon-eds-i-chevron-right-small"></use></svg></a></div></figure></div><p>Pronounced viral RNA and antigen were detected via in situ hybridization (ISH) and immunohistochemistry (IHC) in the mammary gland of affected cows and in the brain (cerebrum, cerebellum and brain stem) of affected cats. In mammary glands, viral RNA and antigen were present in the alveolar milk-secreting epithelial cells and interacinar spaces. In the brain of an affected cat, viral RNA and antigen were detected in neuronal soma glial cells, endothelial cells lining the capillaries within the choroid plexus, and the Purkinje cells in the molecular layer of cerebellum (Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Fig3">3</a> and Extended Data Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Fig8">2</a>). In addition, sparce viral RNA and antigen were detected in the lung, supramammary lymph nodes, spleen, heart, colon and liver from affected cows (Extended Data Table <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="table anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Tab3">3</a> and Extended Data Figs. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Fig9">3</a> and <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Fig10">4</a>). Virus-infected cells were detected in peripheral areas of germinal centres of lymph nodes and in cells surrounding blood vessels in the remaining tissues (Extended Data Table <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="table anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Tab3">3</a> and Extended Data Figs. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Fig9">3</a> and <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Fig10">4</a>). These results demonstrate a distinct tropism of HPAI H5N1 virus for the mammary tissue of cattle and the central nervous system tissue of cats with sporadic detection of virus-infected cells in other tissues.</p></div></div></section><section data-title="Spillover of reassortant H5N1 virus"><div class="c-article-section" id="Sec7-section"><h2 class="c-article-section__title js-section-title js-c-reading-companion-sections-item" id="Sec7">Spillover of reassortant H5N1 virus</h2><div class="c-article-section__content" id="Sec7-content"><p>All HPAI H5N1 virus sequences obtained from the farms in our study (<i>n</i> = 91) were classified within a new reassortant B3.13 genotype (Extended Data Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Fig11">5</a>), which comprises PA, HA, NA and matrix gene segments of an Eurasian wild bird ancestry (ea1), and NS, PB2, PB1, and NP gene segments from American bird lineages (am1.1, am2.2, am4 and am8, respectively; Extended Data Table <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="table anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Tab4">4</a>). To identify potential parental genotypes and to define the most recent common ancestors leading to the emergence of genotype B3.13, we performed Bayesian evolutionary analysis sampling trees (BEAST) and TreeSort sorting using influenza A sequences obtained between 2020 and 2024. This analysis suggests that B3.13 genotype viruses acquired the PB2 and NP gene fragments before its initial detections in avian and mammalian species in January 2024 (Extended Data Table <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="table anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Tab4">4</a> and Extended Data Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Fig11">5</a>). The first genome segment derived from the LPAI American bird lineage to be incorporated in HPAI H5N1 clade 2.3.4.4b was the NS gene (am1.1); the earliest evidence of its emergence derived from a reassortant genotype B3.2 virus obtained from chicken in British Columbia, Canada in June 2022 (A/chicken/BC/22-023547-001-original/2022(H5N1)); Extended Data Table <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="table anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Tab4">4</a>). Incorporation of the PB1 (am4) and PB2 (am2.2) gene segments into HPAI H5N1 clade 2.3.4.4b was first detected in November 2023, in a genotype B3.9 virus sequence recovered from a tundra swan (<i>Cygnus columbianus</i>) from Minnesota (A/tundra_swan/Minnesota/23-037501-001-original/2023(H5N1)). The reassortant genotype B3.13 virus, which incorporated the am2.2 PB2 and am8 NP gene segments, was first detected on 26 November 2023 in Canada goose (<i>Branta canadensis</i>) in Colorado (A/goose/Colorado/23-038138-001/2023), then on 25 January 2024 in a Canada goose (<i>Branta canadensis</i>) in Wyoming (A/Canada_goose/Wyoming/24-003692-001-original/2024(H5N1)), followed by a detection in a peregrine falcon (<i>Falco peregrinus</i>) in California (A/peregrine_falcon/California/24-005915-001-original/2024(H5N1)) on 14 February 2024, and soon after in a skunk in New Mexico on 23 February 2024 (A/skunk/New_Mexico/24-006483-001-original/2024(H5N1); Extended Data Table <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="table anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Tab4">4</a> and Extended Data Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Fig11">5</a>). The host species, in which the reassortment event culminating in the incorporation of the am8 NP segment and emergence of the HPAI H5N1 genotype B3.13 virus, remains unknown.</p></div></div></section><section data-title="Phylogenomics of the H5N1 B3.13 genotype"><div class="c-article-section" id="Sec8-section"><h2 class="c-article-section__title js-section-title js-c-reading-companion-sections-item" id="Sec8">Phylogenomics of the H5N1 B3.13 genotype</h2><div class="c-article-section__content" id="Sec8-content"><p>Phylogenetic analysis based on concatenated whole genomes revealed that all sequences from farms 1 to 9, including sequences obtained from wild birds, cows and other mammals, formed a large monophyletic lineage (Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Fig4">4a</a> and Extended Data Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Fig12">6</a>). They were most closely related to a sequence obtained from the Canada Goose in November 2023 in Colorado (A/goose/Colorado/23-038138-001/2023) and a sequence from a skunk in New Mexico on 23 February 2024 (A/skunk/New_Mexico/24-006483-001-original/2024). The sequences obtained from the affected dairy farms characterized in the present study formed two large phylogenetic branches, with the largest one including three subclusters. Of note, these phylogenetic groups of closely related sequences were not always formed by sequences derived from the same farm (Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Fig4">4b</a>). Phylogenetic branches formed by sequences obtained from cattle from farms 1 and 3, farms 1 and 8, and farms 7 and 9 suggested a close genetic relationship between the viruses in these farms (Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Fig4">4b</a>), and potential transfer of the virus between farms. Similarly, sequences obtained from cattle from sites 1 and 2 of farm 2 (a multisite dairy operation), formed a monophyletic cluster, indicating co-circulation of the virus in these two sites (Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Fig4">4b</a>).</p><div class="c-article-section__figure js-c-reading-companion-figures-item" data-test="figure" data-container-section="figure" id="figure-4" data-title="Phylogenetic analysis of HPAI H5N1."><figure><figcaption><b id="Fig4" class="c-article-section__figure-caption" data-test="figure-caption-text">Fig. 4: Phylogenetic analysis of HPAI H5N1.</b></figcaption><div class="c-article-section__figure-content"><div class="c-article-section__figure-item"><a class="c-article-section__figure-link" data-test="img-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="image" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4/figures/4" rel="nofollow"><picture><source type="image/webp" srcset="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41586-024-07849-4/MediaObjects/41586_2024_7849_Fig4_HTML.png?as=webp"><img aria-describedby="Fig4" src="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41586-024-07849-4/MediaObjects/41586_2024_7849_Fig4_HTML.png" alt="figure 4" loading="lazy" width="685" height="1052"></picture></a></div><div class="c-article-section__figure-description" data-test="bottom-caption" id="figure-4-desc"><p><b>a</b>, Phylogeny of sequences derived from cattle, cats, raccoon and grackle sampled in the farms described in this study, and other sequences in closer ancestral branches, obtained from the GISAID database. Nodes are coloured by host species. <b>b</b>, Detailed view of the clade containing 91 sequences derived from animals sampled in the farms described in this study. Nodes are coloured by farm. All phylogenomic analyses were conducted with concatenated whole-genome sequences.</p></div></div><div class="u-text-right u-hide-print"><a class="c-article__pill-button" data-test="article-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="button" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4/figures/4" data-track-dest="link:Figure4 Full size image" aria-label="Full size image figure 4" rel="nofollow"><span>Full size image</span><svg width="16" height="16" focusable="false" role="img" aria-hidden="true" class="u-icon"><use xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="#icon-eds-i-chevron-right-small"></use></svg></a></div></figure></div><p>Next, the mutation profile of HPAI H5N1 clade 2.3.4.4b was investigated. Initially, we evaluated the occurrence of mutations with known functional relevance to IAV (for example, host adaptation, virulence and host specificity shift, among others) compared with the original H5N1 A/GsGd/1/1996 virus (Supplementary Table <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#MOESM5">3</a>). Furthermore, we performed a detailed comparative genome analysis and mutational profiling using sequences obtained in the USA throughout the 2021–2024 HPAI outbreak (Extended Data Table <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="table anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Tab5">5</a>). The first HPAI H5N1 clade 2.3.4.4b sequence A/chicken/NL/FAV-0033/2021 detected in Canada was used as a reference to identify mutations in different genome segments across affected species. Representative sequences from multiple genotypes (A1, A2, B1.3, B3.2, Minor01, B3.6, B3.9 and B3.13) were selected, including sequences from avian (chicken and great tailed grackle) and mammalian (skunk, red fox, harbour seals, human, goat, cat and cattle) hosts. A total of 132 amino acid substitutions were observed across the 8 genome segments, most of which are low-frequency mutations observed in a small proportion of cattle-derived viral sequences (Extended Data Table <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="table anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Tab5">5</a> and Supplementary Table <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#MOESM8">6</a>). Fifteen mutations emerged in viruses of genotypes circulating in late 2023 (for example, A2 and B3.6) and were maintained in genotype B3.13 viruses in 2024, including mutations in PB2 (V109I, V139I, V495I and V649I), PB1 (E75D, M171V, R430K and A587P), PA (K113R), HA (T211I), NA (V67I, L269M, V321I and S339P), NP (S482N) and NS1 (C116S) genes. Seven additional mutations were detected exclusively in genotype B3.13 viruses, including five substitutions in PB2 (T58A, E362G, D441N, M631L and T676A), one in PA (L219I) and one in NS1 (S7L). When compared with the first reported B3.13 sequences (A/goose/Colorado/23-038138-001/2023[H5N1]), (A/Canada_goose/Wyoming/24-003692-001-original/2024(H5N1)), A/peregrine_falcon/California/24-005915-001-original/2024(H5N1) and A/skunk/New_Mexico/24-006483-001-original/2024(H5N1)), the cow HPAI H5N1 viral sequences presented five amino acid substitutions, including three in PB2 (E362G, D441N and M631L), one in PA (L219I) and one in NS (S7L; Extended Data Table <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="table anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Tab5">5</a>), suggesting that these could have emerged following spillover in cattle.</p></div></div></section><section data-title="H5N1 virus dispersal between farms"><div class="c-article-section" id="Sec9-section"><h2 class="c-article-section__title js-section-title js-c-reading-companion-sections-item" id="Sec9">H5N1 virus dispersal between farms</h2><div class="c-article-section__content" id="Sec9-content"><p>The HPAI H5N1 genotype B3.13 sequences obtained from farms presenting an epidemiological link (farm 2: separate production sites [site 1 and 2]; and farms 1 and 3: animals were transported from farm 1 to 3; Extended Data Table <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="table anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Tab1">1</a>) or presenting closely related viral sequences (farms 7 and 9; Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Fig4">4b</a>) were subjected to phylogeographical dispersal reconstructions (Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Fig5">5a</a>). Haplotype network analysis of concatenated whole-genome sequences provided support for focusing the dispersal and phylogeographical inferences on farms 1 and 3, farm 2, and farms 7 and 9 (Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Fig5">5b</a>). The phylogenetic relationship and dispersal pathways were inferred based on concatenated whole-genome sequences, the farm location and date of sample collection to reconstruct hypothetical dispersal trajectories of the HPAI virus between the farms. The viral sequences recovered from farm 2, which were collected from two separated production sites (1 and 2, approximately 50 km apart), formed two phylogenetic clusters, each comprising sequences from both sites, confirming the spread of the virus between these premises. Phylogeographical dispersal analysis of the HPAI H5N1 sequences recovered from farm 2 suggests site 1 as the likely source of the virus (Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Fig5">5c</a>).</p><div class="c-article-section__figure js-c-reading-companion-figures-item" data-test="figure" data-container-section="figure" id="figure-5" data-title="Interstate and local dispersal of the HPAI H5N1 genotype B3.13 between farms."><figure><figcaption><b id="Fig5" class="c-article-section__figure-caption" data-test="figure-caption-text">Fig. 5: Interstate and local dispersal of the HPAI H5N1 genotype B3.13 between farms.</b></figcaption><div class="c-article-section__figure-content"><div class="c-article-section__figure-item"><a class="c-article-section__figure-link" data-test="img-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="image" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4/figures/5" rel="nofollow"><picture><source type="image/webp" srcset="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41586-024-07849-4/MediaObjects/41586_2024_7849_Fig5_HTML.png?as=webp"><img aria-describedby="Fig5" src="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41586-024-07849-4/MediaObjects/41586_2024_7849_Fig5_HTML.png" alt="figure 5" loading="lazy" width="685" height="575"></picture></a></div><div class="c-article-section__figure-description" data-test="bottom-caption" id="figure-5-desc"><p><b>a</b>, HPAI H5N1 virus dispersal in North America. Samples described in this study are coloured by farm, whereas locations in grey represent samples from closer ancestral branches obtained from the GISAID database. <b>b</b>, Haplotype network analysis of HPAI H5N1 viral sequences obtained from the farms described in this study. The different colours indicate different farms. The size of each vertex is relative to the number of samples, and the dashes on branches denote the number of mutations between nodes. <b>c</b>–<b>e</b>, Phylogenetic reconstruction and analysis of dispersal between sites 1 and 2 of farm 2 (<b>c</b>), farms 7 and 9 (<b>d</b>), and farms 1 and 3 (<b>e</b>). The directions of dispersal lines are counterclockwise. All phylogenomic and dispersal analyses were conducted with concatenated whole-genome sequences.</p></div></div><div class="u-text-right u-hide-print"><a class="c-article__pill-button" data-test="article-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="button" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4/figures/5" data-track-dest="link:Figure5 Full size image" aria-label="Full size image figure 5" rel="nofollow"><span>Full size image</span><svg width="16" height="16" focusable="false" role="img" aria-hidden="true" class="u-icon"><use xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="#icon-eds-i-chevron-right-small"></use></svg></a></div></figure></div><p>Viral sequences obtained from farms 7 and 9 (six sequences from farm 7 and 11 sequences from farm 9), which are approximately 280 km apart from each other, formed a monophyletic cluster, suggesting a link and potential bidirectional virus dispersal between these two farms (Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Fig5">5d</a>). However, another hypothesis that cannot be formally excluded as it could not be resolved by our analysis is unidirectional dispersal of multiple viral lineages from farms 7 to 9 or vice versa. Given the close genetic relationship between the viruses in these farms, we conducted a broader phylogenetic analysis including other HPAI H5N1 B3.13 sequences available in GISIAD. This analysis revealed two additional H5N1 sequences recovered from blackbirds (unknown species) clustering with viral sequences from farms 7 and 9 (Extended Data Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Fig13">7</a>). The blackbirds were collected at 8–12 km away from farm 7. Together, these results suggest both long-range and close-range lateral spread and transmission of the HPAI virus between farms.</p><p>Sequences obtained from farm 1 (Texas) and farm 3 (Ohio) branched interspersedly in two subclusters. Viral sequence recovered from animals from farm 1 were basal to all sequences from farm 3. Phylogeographical dispersal analysis revealed that the HPAI virus most likely spread from farm 1 (Texas) to farm 3 (Ohio; Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Fig5">5e</a>). This is consistent with the epidemiological information revealing the transportation of 42 apparently healthy dairy cattle from farm 1 to farm 3 on 8 March 2024, 5 days before the first clinical signs were observed in animals in farm 1 and 12 days before the first clinical animal was identified in farm 3 (Extended Data Table <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="table anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Tab1">1</a>). These results indicate transmission of HPAI H5N1 virus between subclinically infected cows.</p></div></div></section><section data-title="Interspecies transmission of the H5N1 virus"><div class="c-article-section" id="Sec10-section"><h2 class="c-article-section__title js-section-title js-c-reading-companion-sections-item" id="Sec10">Interspecies transmission of the H5N1 virus</h2><div class="c-article-section__content" id="Sec10-content"><p>Given that five of the nine farms included in our study (farms 1, 3, 4, 5 and 8) reported mortality events in wild (great-tailed grackles) and peri-domestic (pigeons) birds, and in wild (raccoon) and domestic (cats) mammals, we investigated potential HPAI infection in these species. Whole-genome sequencing of the samples from the grackles and a cat from farm 1 and a raccoon from farm 8 confirmed infection of these species with a HPAI H5N1 genotype B3.13 virus closely related to the viruses found in dairy cattle in these farms. The basal sequences for the viruses obtained from a cat in farm 1 and the raccoon in farm 8 were derived from dairy cattle, indicating cattle-to-cat and cattle-to-raccoon transmission (Extended Data Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#Fig14">8</a>). This is supported by epidemiological information revealing that feeding raw milk to farm cats was a common practice in these farms.</p></div></div></section><section data-title="Discussion"><div class="c-article-section" id="Sec11-section"><h2 class="c-article-section__title js-section-title js-c-reading-companion-sections-item" id="Sec11">Discussion</h2><div class="c-article-section__content" id="Sec11-content"><p>Here we described the spillover of a new reassortant HPAI H5N1 virus clade 2.3.4.4b genotype B3.13 into dairy cattle and provide evidence of efficient transmission among cattle and between cattle and other species, highlighting the ability of the virus to cross species barriers. The farms that first reported and confirmed the HPAI H5N1 virus genotype B3.13 infection in cattle in Texas, New Mexico and Kansas are on the Central North American migratory bird flyway. The first reported genome sequence of the genotype B3.13 virus was obtained from a sample collected from a Canada goose in Colorado (26 November 2023) and then in a Canada goose in Wyoming (25 January 2024), within the same flyway. This was followed by detection in a peregrine falcon in California (14 February 2024) on the Pacific flyway, and then in a skunk in New Mexico (23 February 2024), again on the Central flyway. The lack of complete epidemiological information regarding the H5N1 genotype B3.13 sequence collected from the skunk in New Mexico precludes definitive conclusions on the link of this animal with affected dairy cattle farms in the region. However, these findings demonstrate the presence of the virus in wildlife in New Mexico around the same time (January–February 2024) that the first cases of sick cows presenting mild respiratory signs, drop in feed intake and milk production (which were later confirmed to be caused by HPAI H5N1 genotype B3.13) were reported<sup><a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 35" title="Federal and state veterinary, public Health agencies share update on HPAI detection in Kansas, Texas dairy herds. APHIS 
                  https://www.aphis.usda.gov/news/agency-announcements/federal-state-veterinary-public-health-agencies-share-update-hpai
                  
                 (2024)." href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#ref-CR35" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e1500">35</a></sup>. Additional historical and prospective sequence data are needed for more detailed molecular epidemiological inferences.</p><p>Our results demonstrate a high tropism of HPAI H5N1 for the mammary gland tissue resulting in a viral-induced mastitis, which was confirmed by histological changes and direct viral detection in situ, demonstrating viral replication and defining the virus tropism for milk-secreting mammary epithelial cells lining the alveoli in the mammary gland. The tropism of HPAI H5N1 for milk-secreting epithelial cells is consistent with high expression of sialic acid receptors with an α2,3 (avian-like receptor) and α2,6 (human-like receptor) galactose linkage in these cells<sup><a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 36" title="Kristensen, C., Larsen, L. E., Trebbien, R. & Jensen, H. E. The avian influenza A virus receptor SA-α2,3-gal is expressed in the porcine nasal mucosa sustaining the pig as a mixing vessel for new influenza viruses. Virus Res. 340, 199304 (2024)." href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#ref-CR36" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e1507">36</a></sup>. Although the tissue sample size included in our study was small, isolation of the virus in lung and suprammamary lymph nodes (which were also positive for viral RNA and antigen) suggests that other organs may also have a role in the virus infection dynamics and pathogenesis in dairy cattle. The initial site of virus replication remains unknown; however, it is possible that the virus infects through respiratory and/or oral routes replicating at low levels in the upper respiratory tract (for example, nasal turbinate, trachea and/or pharynx), from where it could disseminate to other organs via a short and low-level viraemia. The collected evidence suggests that the mammary gland is the main site of virus replication, resulting in substantial virus shedding in milk. Another possible transmission route includes direct infection of the mammary gland through the teat orifice and cisternae, which could occur through contaminated floors and bedding where animals lay in the farm or mechanically via the milking equipment during milking. This entry route could also lead to viraemia and subsequent virus dissemination/replication in other distant tissue sites. In the 1950s, several studies have shown that direct inoculation of virus into the udder of dairy cows and goats with the human PR8 strain of IAV led to infection and viral shedding<sup><a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Mitchell, C. A., Nordland, O. & Walker, R. V. L. Myxoviruses and their propagation in the mammary gland of ruminants. Can. J. Comp. Med. XXII, 154–156 (1958)." href="#ref-CR37" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e1511">37</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Mitchell, C. A., Walker, R. V. L. & Bannister, G. L. Further experiments relating to the propagation of virus in the bovine mammary gland. Can. J. Comp. Med. XVII, 218–222 (1953)." href="#ref-CR38" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e1511_1">38</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Mitchell, C. A., Walker, R. V. L. & Bannister, G. L. Persistence of neutralizing antibody in milk and blood of cows and goats following the instillation of virus into the mammary gland. Can. J. Comp. Med. XVIII, 426–430 (1954)." href="#ref-CR39" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e1511_2">39</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Mitchell, C. A., Walker, R. V. & Bannister, G. L. Preliminary experiments relating to the propagation of viruses in the bovine mammary gland. Can. J. Comp. Med. Vet. Sci. 17, 97–104 (1953)." href="#ref-CR40" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e1511_3">40</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 41" title="Mitchell, C. A., Walker, R. V. & Bannister, G. L. Studies relating to the formation of neutralizing antibody following the propagation of influenza and Newcastle disease virus in the bovine mammary gland. Can. J. Microbiol. 2, 322–328 (1956)." href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#ref-CR41" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e1514">41</a></sup>. These results suggest, considering the current outbreak, that mammary epithelial cells, which express α2,3 and α2,6 sialic acid<sup><a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 36" title="Kristensen, C., Larsen, L. E., Trebbien, R. & Jensen, H. E. The avian influenza A virus receptor SA-α2,3-gal is expressed in the porcine nasal mucosa sustaining the pig as a mixing vessel for new influenza viruses. Virus Res. 340, 199304 (2024)." href="/articles/s41586-024-07849-4#ref-CR36" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e1518">36</a></sup>, may be generally susceptible to IAVs. There are a few studies that have suggested an association between IAV and clinical disease<sup><a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Sreenivasan, C. C., Thomas, M., Kaushik, R. S., Wang, D. & Li, F. Influenza A in bovine species: a narrative literature review. Viruses 11, 561 (2019)." href="#ref-CR42" id="ref-link-section-d27872839e1522">42</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Campbell, C. H., Easterday, B. C. & Webster, R. G. Strains of Hong Kong influenza virus in calves. J. Infect.
